fields.label: Patient name

groups.label: Date
If the area is fairly small, it will be possible to close the wound by bringing the edges of the skin together. Larger wounds may need a skin graft to cover the area.
This may take 18 months to 2 years to fade and become paler. Sometimes this takes longer and the graft may never be exactly the same colour as the rest of the skin.
The skin graft may not feel as smooth as the rest of your skin, given time this may improve but will never be the same as the skin was before the grafting.
1. Split skin grafts: involves the top layer of skin (epidermis) and a small part of the underneath or deep layer (dermis).
2. Full thickness skin grafts: involves all the layers of the skin and deeper tissues.
• Reduced pain and discomfort when dressings are changed
• Risk of infection is reduced
• Chance of scarring is reduced
• Occasionally the skin graft may breakdown. This results in prolonged healing time and can result in increased scarring.
• You will have some discomfort in the next 24-48 hours after the procedure. Take pain medication as prescribed by your doctor.
• It is common for the area around the surgery site to feel numb or hypersensitive to touch but should improve with time.
• The donor site area is usually more painful than the grafted area as the top layers of the skin are removed exposing the nerve endings.
• Regular pain killers will need to be given to ease the discomfort.
Activities:
• Take things gently for 2 weeks to allow the skin graft to heal properly.
• The grafted area is quite fragile, so it is important not to rub or brush against the graft or the dressing, or put pressure on the area.
• Bandage or tubigrip (elastic stocking) is applied to put pressure and to prevent swelling.
• If the skin graft is anywhere other than your leg(s), you can start walking as soon as you feel up to it.
• If it is on one or both of your legs, then we encourage limited mobility for around 2 days or until the skin graft is secure enough for walking. Please elevate when resting.
• If the skin graft is on your hand, you may have a sling to keep your arm raised as much as you can.
• Avoid vigorous activities that require pushing, pulling, stretching or heavy lifting. Strenuous activity may cause bleeding particularly 24 - 48 hours after surgery.
• You may need 3 - 4 weeks off work if you have had a skin graft to your leg.
• When the skin graft has healed properly you should be able to carry on with your normal activities.
Wound Infection:
If you experience any of the below, please get in contact with our team.
• Smelly discharge from dressing
• High temperature
• Increased pain
• Redness and swelling around the skin flap
• Bleeding through the dressing caused by trauma or infection
• Loss of the graft caused by trauma, friction or infection

fields.label: Date

Skin graft is a surgical procedure where a piece of healthy skin is taken from one area of the body and placed over where the cancer has been removed. The area where the skin is taken from is called a donor site. The graft may be held in place by stitches. The graft heals by taking up blood supply from the base of the wound thereby allowing the grafted skin to survive.

groups.label: With any skin graft, scar formation is inevitable. At first the graft will look a different colour to the rest of your skin, usually dark reddish purple.
The two most common are split skin grafts and full thickness skin grafts.
• An effective way to assist wound healing when there has been a loss of skin due to conditions that involve disease, injuries including burns, or surgical removal of skin cancer
• Skin grafts may become infected or bleed like any other skin procedure.

• The common areas used as donor sites are the buttocks, thighs and upper arms. The donor site is dressed in the clinic with fixomull and the dressing will sometimes be left in place for 7–10 days and will need to be kept dry for that period.
We normally like to see all patients who have had a skin flap 5 - 7 days after the operation. The stitches are usually removed and the doctor will check that there are no problems.

fields.label: If the area is fairly small, it will be possible to close the wound by bringing the edges of the skin together. Larger wounds may need a skin graft to cover the area.

sections.name: What will the skin graft look like?

fields.label: With any skin graft, scar formation is inevitable. At first the graft will look a different colour to the rest of your skin, usually dark reddish purple.
This may take 18 months to 2 years to fade and become paler. Sometimes this takes longer and the graft may never be exactly the same colour as the rest of the skin.
The skin graft may not feel as smooth as the rest of your skin, given time this may improve but will never be the same as the skin was before the grafting.
The two most common are split skin grafts and full thickness skin grafts.
1. Split skin grafts: involves the top layer of skin (epidermis) and a small part of the underneath or deep layer (dermis).
2. Full thickness skin grafts: involves all the layers of the skin and deeper tissues.

sections.name: What are the benefits of having a skin graft?

fields.label: • An effective way to assist wound healing when there has been a loss of skin due to conditions that involve disease, injuries including burns, or surgical removal of skin cancer
• Reduced pain and discomfort when dressings are changed
• Risk of infection is reduced
• Chance of scarring is reduced

sections.name: Risk or complications of skin grafts

fields.label: • Skin grafts may become infected or bleed like any other skin procedure.
• Occasionally the skin graft may breakdown. This results in prolonged healing time and can result in increased scarring.
• You will have some discomfort in the next 24-48 hours after the procedure. Take pain medication as prescribed by your doctor.
• It is common for the area around the surgery site to feel numb or hypersensitive to touch but should improve with time.

• The common areas used as donor sites are the buttocks, thighs and upper arms. The donor site is dressed in the clinic with fixomull and the dressing will sometimes be left in place for 7–10 days and will need to be kept dry for that period.
• The donor site area is usually more painful than the grafted area as the top layers of the skin are removed exposing the nerve endings.
• Regular pain killers will need to be given to ease the discomfort.
We normally like to see all patients who have had a skin flap 5 - 7 days after the operation. The stitches are usually removed and the doctor will check that there are no problems.
Activities:
• Take things gently for 2 weeks to allow the skin graft to heal properly.
• The grafted area is quite fragile, so it is important not to rub or brush against the graft or the dressing, or put pressure on the area.
• Bandage or tubigrip (elastic stocking) is applied to put pressure and to prevent swelling.
• If the skin graft is anywhere other than your leg(s), you can start walking as soon as you feel up to it.
• If it is on one or both of your legs, then we encourage limited mobility for around 2 days or until the skin graft is secure enough for walking. Please elevate when resting.
• If the skin graft is on your hand, you may have a sling to keep your arm raised as much as you can.
• Avoid vigorous activities that require pushing, pulling, stretching or heavy lifting. Strenuous activity may cause bleeding particularly 24 - 48 hours after surgery.
• You may need 3 - 4 weeks off work if you have had a skin graft to your leg.
• When the skin graft has healed properly you should be able to carry on with your normal activities.
Wound Infection:
If you experience any of the below, please get in contact with our team.
• Smelly discharge from dressing
• High temperature
• Increased pain
• Redness and swelling around the skin flap
• Bleeding through the dressing caused by trauma or infection
• Loss of the graft caused by trauma, friction or infection

sections.name: If you need more information or have any concerns we are only a phone or email call away.
